overview_of_class:
WRITING THE FEATURE FILM
COURSE DESCRIPTION

Students in this intensive workshop will learn to write and analyze feature films with emphasis on emotional logic, plot logic and organization, seeking mastery of all aspects of the art and craft of screenwriting. The class will be structured through lectures, reading assignments, viewing of streamed films, discussion, in-class viewing of film clips and workshop of student assignments. Writing assignments will be arranged to mirror a writer's creative process starting with ideas and culminating in the successful completion of a plot outline and a minimum of 30 to 40 pages of an original feature-length screenplay. An alternative track toward completing the page requirements may be available. Students may complete a plot outline and an entire first draft of a feature screenplay with a submission schedule determined in consultation with instructor.
Pre-requisite: RTVF 260 Copying Estimate: 300 pages
Required textbooks:
Howard, David (2004). How to Build a Great Screenplay: A Master Class in Storytelling for Film [Paperback] New York: St. Martin's Griffin. # ISBN-10: 031235262X; # ISBN-13: 978-0312352622
Waldeback, Zara and Batty, Craig (2012). The Creative Screenwriter. New York: Methuen Drama. #ISBN-13 9781408137192

Writing the Dramatic Pilot
Overview of class
Students in this intensive workshop will learn to write and analyze the dramatic pilot with emphasis on dramatic pilot structure, character creation and organization. Through lectures, reading assignments, discussion, in-class viewing of selected television clips and in-class workshop of student assignments, students will work toward mastering the creation of the modern dramatic pilot.

overview_of_class: This course will explore: What are some of the current issues facing the LGBTQIA community? Which of the groups within this community are the most underrepresented? Where is LGBTQIA headed in terms of television/theater, and what could the future hold? How do you tell a story that centers around LGBTQIA characters using the context of theatre/ TV ? Students will leave this course with a revised draft of a one act play, or half hour television episode.

overview_of_class:
Writing the Inspirational Film
That movie changed my life. That play made me a better person. I laughed. I cried. I was inspired or transformed. Is there an art and craft to the creation of these types of stories or are their emotional effects more a matter of personal inclination? Different strokes for different folks or is there a method to the madness? What is the story mechanism that drives It's a Wonderful Life, To Kill a Mockingbird or Groundhog Day to make them inspirational? Why do we cry at Love, Actually, laugh at Some Like It Hot or scream at Halloween? One of the goals of this class will be to place Aristotle's theory of catharsis, the purgative release from pity and fear, into a modern context. Is there a common thread between Oedipus Rex, Romeo and Juliet and The Lion King? Are there narrative strategies to employ to emotionally engage and release an audience? And on a personal level, might the process of creating such a narrative ultimately transform the author as well? Students in this advanced media writing class will collaborate to answer these questions and define what it means to write an inspirational/transformational script. Their projects will be developed through mastery of all elements of the art and craft of scriptwriting. Particular emphasis will be placed on character development. Each student will create a complete outline and write at least thirty to forty pages for an inspirational feature-length film or play. At their option, students may complete their scripts during the class. This workshop course will be augmented by readings, lectures, discussion, in-class viewing and at-home streaming of selected films.

Pre-Requisite: RTVF 260. Estimated Copies: 300
Required textbooks:
Howard, David (2004). How to Build a Great Screenplay: A Master Class in Storytelling for Film [Paperback] New York: St. Martin's Griffin. # ISBN-10: 031235262X; # ISBN-13: 978-0312352622
Waldeback, Zara and Batty, Craig (2012). The Creative Screenwriter. New York: Methuen Drama. #ISBN-13 9781408137192

overview_of_class:
Writing The Fact-based Drama
RTVF 360

In this class, we will investigate the fraught and complicated relationship between truth and fiction by researching and writing our own "fact-based" dramatic scripts. From the "living newspapers" of the 1930's to today's "verbatim theatre," from documentary film to narrative drama "based on a true story," non-fiction can provide dramatists with a rich vein of material and raise fascinating issues about the differences between historical and artistic truth.

There will be weekly reading assignments, and each student will assemble an original portfolio of fact-based sources (historical research, contemporary interviews, photographs and video footage, etc.) and write at least 30 pages of a new play, film, or television script (narrative or documentary) drawn from that non-fiction material.

CLASS MATERIALS (REQUIRED):

? Aristotle, The Rhetoric and the Poetics
? Lynn Nottage, Ruined
? Moises Kaufman and the Tectonic Theatre Project, The Laramie Project
? Anna Deavere Smith, Fires in the Mirror
? Screenplay readings and films available on reserve and online via CANVAS.

Working computer, internet access, NU email/account, word processing program
